text: Rufus King Goodenow (April 24, 1790 - March 24, 1863) was a United States Representative from Maine. Born in Henniker, New Hampshire, he moved with his parents to Brownfield, Maine in 1802. He received limited schooling, subsequently engaged in agricultural pursuits. He also made several voyages to European ports and served as a captain in the Thirty-third Regiment, United States Infantry, in the War of 1812. He moved to Paris, Maine in 1821. He was the brother of Robert Goodenow. He served as clerk of the Oxford County Courts from 1821 to 1837. Goodenow was elected a member of the Maine House of Representatives. He was a delegate to the Whig National Convention at Harrisburg, Pennsylvania in 1839. He studied law, was admitted to the bar and practiced in the courts of Maine. He was elected as a Whig to the Thirty-first Congress (March 4, 1849 - March 4, 1851), and died in Paris, Maine. He was interred in Riverside Cemetery. ==References== Category:1790 births Category:1863 deaths Category:People from Henniker, New Hampshire Category:Maine Whigs Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Maine Category:American army personnel of the War of 1812 Category:People from Brownfield, Maine Category:Whig Party members of the United States House of Representatives Category:19th-century American politicians Category:People from Paris, Maine Category:United States Army officers
title: Rufus K. Goodenow
